articles.headline: Food Companies Are Placing the Onus for Safety on Consumers
articles.snippet: Makers of processed foods have increased their efforts to eliminate pathogens, but with uneven results.
articles.abstract: Makers of processed foods have increased their efforts to eliminate pathogens, but with uneven results.
articles.lead_paragraph: The frozen pot pies that sickened an estimated 15,000 people with salmonella in 2007 left federal inspectors mystified. At first they suspected the turkey. Then they considered the peas, carrots and potatoes.

articles.headline: Afghan Villagers Describe Chaos of U.S. Strikes
articles.snippet: The number of civilians killed by U.S. airstrikes in Farah Province last week may never be fully known, but villagers tell stories of devastation.
articles.abstract: The number of civilians killed by U.S. airstrikes in Farah Province last week may never be fully known, but villagers tell stories of devastation.
articles.lead_paragraph: FARAH, Afghanistan  The number of civilians killed by the American airstrikes in Farah Province last week may never be fully known. But villagers, including two girls recovering from burn wounds, described devastation that officials and human rights workers are calling the worst episode of civilian casualties in eight years of war in Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Taimoor Shah

articles.headline: Angry Ads Seek to Channel Consumer Outrage
articles.snippet: Many advertisers are being unusually outspoken and provocative to reach consumers hit hard by the recession.
articles.abstract: Many advertisers are being unusually outspoken and provocative to reach consumers hit hard by the recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: The mad men of Madison Avenue are really mad these days, creating a spate of angry advertising campaigns that seek to channel the outrage, frustration and fear felt by consumers hit hard by what some are calling the Great Recession.

articles.headline: A Bank Is Survived by Its Loans
articles.snippet: One bank, World Savings, offered beguiling mortgages, with tiny payments until the loan balance was 25 percent greater than the home’s starting value.
articles.abstract: One bank, World Savings, offered beguiling mortgages, with tiny payments until the loan balance was 25 percent greater than the home’s starting value.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a mortgage market gone crazy with generous loans, no one was more generous than World Savings.

articles.headline: Mexican Data Show Migration to U.S. in Decline
articles.snippet: The trend suggests that illegal immigrants from Mexico are drawn by jobs and stay away in a bad labor market.
articles.abstract: The trend suggests that illegal immigrants from Mexico are drawn by jobs and stay away in a bad labor market.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICALI, Mexico  Census data from the Mexican government indicate an extraordinary decline in the number of Mexican immigrants going to the United States.

articles.headline: Inquiry Focuses on Ex-Pension Official for Bush
articles.snippet: The former Bush administration official is under investigation for inappropriate contacts with Wall Street firms seeking to obtain lucrative contracts.
articles.abstract: The former Bush administration official is under investigation for inappropriate contacts with Wall Street firms seeking to obtain lucrative contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The former Bush administration official in charge of the federal agency that guarantees pensions for 44 million Americans is under investigation over his contacts with several major Wall Street firms seeking to obtain lucrative contracts.

articles.headline: Six Insurers Named to Get U.S. Taxpayer Aid
articles.snippet: The insurers getting bailout money have suffered, but not to the same extent as American International Group.
articles.abstract: The insurers getting bailout money have suffered, but not to the same extent as American International Group.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six major insurance companies have received preliminary approval to get billions of dollars in fresh capital as part of the government’s financial rescue program, a Treasury Department spokesman confirmed on Thursday.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Diana B. Henriques

articles.headline: Go-Between Tied Funds to Carlyle
articles.snippet: David Leuschen, formerly an energy specialist with Goldman Sachs, brought in billions from state pension funds to a joint venture with the Carlyle Group.
articles.abstract: David Leuschen, formerly an energy specialist with Goldman Sachs, brought in billions from state pension funds to a joint venture with the Carlyle Group.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Carlyle Group, celebrated for its political ties as well as its global investment prowess, was eager to expand in the energy business. David M. Leuschen, a specialist in oil and energy at Goldman Sachs, wanted a partner to help him lure big investors.

articles.headline: In Ecuador, Resentment of an Oil Company Oozes
articles.snippet: Chevron acquired Texaco, and with it the former oil fields that some say made them ill.
articles.abstract: Chevron acquired Texaco, and with it the former oil fields that some say made them ill.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHUSHUFINDI, Ecuador  Mention to Anita Ruíz the name of the giant oil company Chevron, and she trembles with rage. At her wooden hut here in the Amazon forest, where oil-project flares illuminate the night sky, she points to a portrait of her youngest son, who died seven years ago of leukemia at age 16.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Companies Object to Google Policy on Trademarks
articles.snippet: Google accepts competitive uses of trademarks, prompting some companies to seek legal action.
articles.abstract: Google accepts competitive uses of trademarks, prompting some companies to seek legal action.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  When Audrey Spangenberg idly typed “FirePond,” the name of her small software company, into Google this year, she was not happy with what she saw.
